text:
Hi, and welcome to your
embedded ethics module

on encoding human
values in technology.

Let's begin by talking about
the main framework of values
in design.

Now, this entire framework
is based on the idea

that design decisions
are expressive of what
we care about.

When we create a
certain technology

and we design the features
of that technology,

those decisions
encode our values,

including efficiency, privacy,
beauty, truth, fairness,
sustainability, and others.
Take the example of Pi.

This is a personal AI
or a conversational bot

that was designed, more or
less recently, by the company
Inflection AI.

Now, a personal AI is designed
to provide a conversational

partner for people who
cannot, or for some reason,

don't want to have conversations
with other human beings.

Now, this kind of
technology may be

driven by values, such as
empathy, respect, solidarity,
kindness, support, et cetera.

You can see how these
values are quite

apparent in the kind
of language that

is generated by the chatbot
and the kinds of conversations
that it offers to users.

It is embedded into
the user interface

and all kinds of features that
are part of the technology.

Now, in the case of Pi,
values emerge quite clearly

from the designer's
definition of the problem

that the technology
tries to address

and the specification
of design features

that allow the product
to solve that problem.

Now, these decisions on
the part of the designer

interact with user's perceptions
and the broader context
in which the design is employed.

Now, when trying to
identify the values coded

into any form of
technology, there's
two things that we should do.

Locate these values
and define them.

So let me talk about
each of these in turn.

To locate values, we need to
look at the key influences that
shape the design process.

This includes looking at,
who are the key actors?
The designers, of course.

But also, who are
the shareholders?
Who are the users?

Then there's the
functional description.

What problem or need is
this technology addressing?

It may turn out to be that the
very problem or the very target

that is sought by
the technology is
specified in terms of values.

Take the example of
privacy-enhancing web browsers.

Now, one thing we should
also look at is constraints.

These constraints
may be economic.
They may be technical.
They may be commercial.
They may be legal.

And all of these
shape design decisions

that will then end up
embedding one value or another
into the technology.

And lastly, there's
societal input.

So culture and social mores
will shape what we can do

and how it is
interpreted by users.

Now, having identified
these sources of influence,

you want to consider how
they shape the design,

in what ways they channel users'
and others' interpretations

of the values that are
embedded in that design.

Now, here I want to
call your attention

to a very important concept
that Helen Nissenbaum refers
to as collateral values.

These are values that
crop up as side effects

of design decisions,
even though they're not
intended by designers.

So if you remember,
the values that

are coded into a
product like Pi,

they're quite explicit
and quite deliberate.

Now, collateral values
are not like that.

They arise or they emerge from
the way in which the design
interacts with the world.

Now, these are
important because they

may drive serious wedges
between what designers

intend to express
and what they end up
expressing in their design.

They drive wedges
between intentions
and actual impacts in the world.

One particular way in which
values may unintendedly crop up
is through standardization.

Standardization happens when
we make implicit assumptions

about who the standard user
is for a given technology

or who the standard
person is who

is going to benefit
from this technology.

Now, this is crucial because
default assumptions are often

a reflection of existing
power imbalances.

And when they go
unquestioned, they

contribute to reinforce those
imbalances by unwillingly

discriminating against
those who do not resemble

that standard user or
the standard person that

is meant to benefit
from this technology.

Biases play a crucial
role in standardization.

And these may include
pre-existing biases

that are already in society,
in culture, or in institutions;

technical biases;
or emergent biases,

biases that emerge when
the product is used

in a context that is different
from its original context
of use.

So when we assume that certain
standard user for a product

is the person that we're
going to be designing for,

we assume that everybody
else is a nonstandard user.

And this places a burden of
sorts on members of the groups

that we fail to
consider or that we

fail to include in our design
because it is harder for them

to use the product and
to benefit from it.
Sometimes that's OK.

Every single
decision that we make

places burdens on some
people and not others.

Every single
decision that we make

provides benefits to some
people and not others.
But these decisions aggregate.

And if all of the burdens fall
on the same group or groups

of people, then we
enter into problems
of distributive justice.

Now, a lot of decisions about
what can be offered and what

needs to be addressed may
be constrained by technical

or economic consideration,
but some aren't.

And it's important that we
treat them as decisions,

as decisions about who we
are benefiting when we design
technology in a certain way.

Here's one interesting
example of how

bias can be encoded
into an AI system

and how bias can be encoded by
taking one default viewpoint.

So Perspective API offers
an automated detection

of toxic contents and toxicity
mitigation, which is crucial

when you're building
a large language model

but also for tasks like
semi-automated content

moderation that happens
in digital platforms

or in public forums
of all kinds.

Now, in a paper that was
published a couple of years

ago by researchers
from DeepMind,

they analyzed the
toxicity scores generated

by Perspective API
and how they impacted
different groups of people.

One of their key insights was
to look into the definition
of toxicity.

If you see on the screen,
the definition of toxicity

is rude, disrespectful,
or unreasonable language

that is likely to make
someone leave a discussion.

Now, the authors of
this paper noticed

that this definition already
builds biases into the system.

For one thing, it is somewhat
subjective and dependent

on the cultural
background of whoever

is reading a piece of content
and the kinds of sensitivities
that they might have.

For another thing, it
covers only a subset
of possibly harmful content.

It does not cover, for instance,
harmful stereotypes that

may be perpetuated by
something like an LLM.

But most importantly,
this definition

prioritizes the interests
of the main customers

for Perspective API, namely,
the digital platforms that

are using these toxicity
mitigation tools.

For these customers,
their business model
depends on user engagement.

So a definition of toxicity that
focuses on what makes somebody

leave a discussion
is one that seeks

to protect the interests
of those customers.

However, this definition
does not necessarily

build in the interests
of users themselves.

So there's one group that
is being prioritized,

whose interests are being
prioritized over others.

This constitutes a good
example of collateral values

cropping up through
default assumptions that

get built into
something as basic

as the definition of the key
metric in Perspective AI.

So once that we have
located the values that

are explicitly or implicitly
embedded in design decisions,

it is important
to define values.
Why is that?

Because ethical and
political values

are abstract, controversial,
and difficult to define.

Definition and analysis allows
us to connect abstract values

that we want to encode or
embed in our technologies
to concrete design features.

If values are not
well-defined, products
can entirely miss their marks.

So it is not simply a matter
of philosophical exercises.

It's a way of securing that
you embed the values that you

actually want to embed into the
technologies that you create.

Think about an example that
I find really interesting,

so thinking about some of
Microsoft's early chatbots
from around 10 years ago.

Microsoft tried
to create chatbots
that were inclusive to people.

Now, if you want to make
something inclusive,

one possible
definition of inclusion

is to make a technology
that is welcoming

to any kind of content
and any kind of topic
that users are interested in.

That was the approach that
was taken by Microsoft when

they designed their
now infamous Tay.

Tay was, as you
may know, targeted

by a campaign
coordinated on 4chan

and ended up becoming
highly racist and sexist

in a matter of hours, to
the point that Microsoft
had to take it down.

Now, after Tay,
Microsoft designed Zo.

And Zo had a different
definition of inclusion,

namely, protecting
vulnerable users from insult
and psychological harm.

And the way that it did it was
by blacklisting certain words

or topics and rejecting
any conversation that
went into those areas.

Now, that also led to
the outright exclusion

of users who wanted to
talk about, say, being
bullied for religious reasons.

So that didn't quite
do the job either.

The point here is that the
definition of inclusion

was something that needed
to be considered more

carefully in this case so
that the products did not

miss the mark completely
as these two chatbots did.

Now, to finalize, I want to
talk about value conflicts.

Now, value conflicts
are a crucial part

of the story because they
are ubiquitous, not just
in technology but everywhere.

We are used to discussing
value conflicts
in policymaking or in politics.

But also in design
decisions, they're important.

They arise even in relatively
uncontroversial contexts.

And this is not the
result of poor design.

It is the inevitable
consequence of recognizing

that different
things matter to us,

to different degrees sometimes,
but often to the same degree.

And that makes it hard
to choose between things
that are truly important.

This is a result of
value pluralism, which
we recognize as a society.

Now, although these
conflicts are everywhere,

and although they may
appear intractable,

this does not mean that we
should throw up our hands.

Rather, we should strive to
make deliberate, conscientious,

and responsible choices in
how we deal with these value
conflicts.

The values and design
framework describes

three different approaches
to value conflicts.

There is dissolving
the conflict,

which means finding an
alternative path that
avoids the conflict entirely.

There's compromising,
which means

making design decisions that
put boundaries on some values

to protect others,
and vice versa.

So finding some kind
of middle ground,

where some part of what we value
on both sides may be attained.

And lastly, there
is trading off,

which means that
we simply decide

to prioritize one value and
sacrifice others for its sake.

Now, different situations may
call for different approaches.

But what matters, again,
is that these decisions

are made deliberately
and responsibly,

that we know that we
are making sacrifices

and how these sacrifices
are likely to impact

different people so that we can,
to the best of our capacity,

mitigate the negative
impacts of our decisions.
And that is all.
Thank you very much.
